pageProps.body:
99 Additional Bits of Unsolicited Advice

99 Additional Bits of Unsolicited Advice

I have another birthday, and another bunch of unsolicited advice.¬†

‚Ä¢¬†That thing that made you weird as a kid could make you great as an adult ‚Äî if you don‚Äôt lose it.

‚Ä¢¬†If you have any doubt at all about being able to carry a load in one trip, do yourself a huge favor and make two trips.

‚Ä¢¬†What you get by achieving your goals is not as important as what you become by achieving your goals. At your funeral people will not recall what you did; they will only remember how you made them feel.

‚Ä¢ Recipe for success: under-promise and over-deliver.

‚Ä¢ It‚Äôs not an apology if it comes with an excuse. It is not a compliment if it comes with a request.

‚Ä¢ Jesus, Superman, and Mother Teresa never made art. Only imperfect beings can make art because art begins in what is broken.

‚Ä¢¬†If someone is trying to convince you it‚Äôs not a pyramid scheme, it‚Äôs a pyramid scheme.

‚Ä¢ Learn how to tie a bowline knot. Practice in the dark. With one hand. For the rest of your life you‚Äôll use this knot more times than you would ever believe.

‚Ä¢¬†If something fails where you thought it would fail, that is not a failure.

‚Ä¢¬†Be governed not by the tyranny of the urgent but by the elevation of the important.

‚Ä¢¬†Leave a gate behind you the way you first found it.

‚Ä¢ The greatest rewards come from working on something that nobody has a name for. If you possibly can, work where there are no words for what you do.

‚Ä¢ A balcony or porch needs to be at least 6 feet (2m) deep or it won‚Äôt be used.

‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt create things to make money; make money so you can create things. The reward for good work is more work.

‚Ä¢ In all things ‚Äî except love ‚Äî start with the exit strategy. Prepare for the ending. Almost anything is easier to get into than out of.

‚Ä¢¬†Train employees well enough they could get another job, but treat them well enough so they never want to.

‚Ä¢¬†Don‚Äôt aim to have others like you; aim to have them respect you.

‚Ä¢¬†The foundation of maturity: Just because it‚Äôs not your fault doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not your responsibility.

‚Ä¢ A multitude of bad ideas is necessary for one good idea.

‚Ä¢ Being wise means having more questions than answers.

‚Ä¢ Compliment people behind their back. It‚Äôll come back to you.

‚Ä¢ Most overnight successes ‚Äî in fact any significant successes ‚Äî take at least 5 years. Budget your life accordingly.

‚Ä¢¬†You are only as young as the last time you changed your mind.

‚Ä¢¬†Assume anyone asking for your account information for any reason is guilty of scamming you, unless proven innocent. The way to prove innocence is to call them back, or login to your account using numbers or a website that you provide, not them. Don‚Äôt release any identifying information while they are contacting you via phone, message or email. You must control the channel.

‚Ä¢¬†Sustained outrage makes you stupid.

‚Ä¢ Be strict with yourself and forgiving of others. The reverse is hell for everyone.

‚Ä¢ Your best response to an insult is ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre probably right.‚Äù Often they are.

‚Ä¢ The worst evils in history have always been committed by those who truly believed they were combating evil. Beware of combating evil.

‚Ä¢¬†If you can avoid seeking approval of others, your power is limitless.

‚Ä¢¬†When a child asks an endless string of ‚Äúwhy?‚Äù questions, the smartest reply is, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, what do you think?‚Äù

‚Ä¢ To be wealthy, accumulate all those things that money can‚Äôt buy.

‚Ä¢ Be the change you wish to see.

‚Ä¢¬†When brainstorming, improvising, jamming with others, you‚Äôll go much further and deeper if you build upon each contribution with a playful ‚Äúyes ‚Äî and‚Äù example instead of a deflating ‚Äúno ‚Äî but‚Äù reply.

‚Ä¢¬†Work to become, not to acquire.

‚Ä¢¬†Don‚Äôt loan money to a friend unless you are ready to make it a gift.

‚Ä¢¬†On the way to a grand goal, celebrate the smallest victories as if each one were the final goal. No matter where it ends you are victorious.

‚Ä¢ Calm is contagious.

‚Ä¢ Even a foolish person can still be right about most things. Most conventional wisdom is true.

‚Ä¢¬†Always cut away from yourself.

‚Ä¢ Show me your calendar and I will tell you your priorities. Tell me who your friends are, and I‚Äôll tell you where you‚Äôre going.

‚Ä¢ When hitchhiking, look like the person you want to pick you up.

‚Ä¢¬†Contemplating the weaknesses of others is easy; contemplating the weaknesses in yourself is hard, but it pays a much higher reward.

‚Ä¢ Worth repeating: measure twice, cut once.

‚Ä¢ Your passion in life should fit you exactly; but your purpose in life should exceed you. Work for something much larger than yourself.

‚Ä¢ If you can‚Äôt tell what you desperately need, it‚Äôs probably sleep.

‚Ä¢ When playing Monopoly, spend all you have to buy, barter, or trade for the Orange properties. Don‚Äôt bother with Utilities.

‚Ä¢ If you borrow something, try to return it in better shape than you received it. Clean it, sharpen it, fill it up.

‚Ä¢ Even in the tropics it gets colder at night than you think. Pack warmly.

‚Ä¢ To quiet a crowd or a drunk, just whisper.

‚Ä¢ Writing down one thing you are grateful for each day is the cheapest possible therapy ever.

‚Ä¢ When someone tells you something is wrong, they‚Äôre usually right. When someone tells you how to fix it, they‚Äôre usually wrong.

‚Ä¢ If you think you saw a mouse, you did. And, if there is one, there are more.

‚Ä¢ Money is overrated. Truly new things rarely need an abundance of money. If that was so, billionaires would have a monopoly on inventing new things, and they don‚Äôt. Instead almost all breakthroughs are made by those who lack money, because they are forced to rely on their passion, persistence and ingenuity to figure out new ways. Being poor is an advantage in innovation.

‚Ä¢ Ignore what others may be thinking of you, because they aren‚Äôt.

‚Ä¢ Avoid hitting the snooze button. That‚Äôs just training you to oversleep.

‚Ä¢ Always say less than necessary.

‚Ä¢ You are given the gift of life in order to discover what your gift *in* life is. You will complete your mission when you figure out what your mission is. This is not a paradox. This is the way.

‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt treat people as bad as they are. Treat them as good as you are.

‚Ä¢ It is much easier to change how you think by changing your behavior, than it is to change your behavior by changing how you think. Act out the change you seek.

‚Ä¢ You can eat any dessert you want if you take only 3 bites.

‚Ä¢ Each time you reach out to people, bring them a blessing; then they‚Äôll be happy to see you when you bring them a problem.

‚Ä¢ Bad things can happen fast, but almost all good things happen slowly.

‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt worry how or where you begin. As long as you keep moving, your success will be far from where you start.

‚Ä¢ When you confront a stuck bolt or screw: righty tighty, lefty loosey.

‚Ä¢ If you meet a jerk, overlook them. If you meet jerks everywhere everyday, look deeper into yourself.

‚Ä¢ Dance with your hips.

‚Ä¢ We are not bodies that temporarily have souls. We are souls that temporarily have bodies.

‚Ä¢ You can reduce the annoyance of someone‚Äôs stupid belief by increasing your understanding of why they believe it.

‚Ä¢ If your goal does not have a schedule, it is a dream.

‚Ä¢ All the greatest gains in life ‚Äî in wealth, relationships, or knowledge ‚Äîcome from the magic of compounding interest ‚Äî amplifying small steady gains. All you need for abundance is to keep adding 1% more than you subtract on a regular basis.

‚Ä¢ The greatest breakthroughs are missed because they look like hard work.

‚Ä¢ People can‚Äôt remember more than 3 points from a speech.

‚Ä¢¬†I have never met a person I admired who did not read more books than I did.

‚Ä¢ The greatest teacher is called ‚Äúdoing‚Äù.

‚Ä¢ Finite games are played to win or lose. Infinite games are played to keep the game going. Seek out infinite games because they yield infinite rewards.

‚Ä¢ Everything is hard before it is easy. The day before something is a breakthrough, it‚Äôs a stupid idea.

‚Ä¢¬†A problem that can be solved with money is not really a problem.

‚Ä¢ When you are stuck, sleep on it. Let your subconscious work for you.

‚Ä¢¬†Your work will be endless, but your time is finite. You cannot limit the work so you must limit your time. Hours are the only thing you can manage.

‚Ä¢¬†To succeed, get other people to pay you; to become wealthy, help other people to succeed.

‚Ä¢ Children totally accept ‚Äî and crave ‚Äî family rules. ‚ÄúIn our family we have a rule for X‚Äù is the only excuse a parent needs for setting a family policy. In fact, ‚ÄúI have a rule for X‚Äù is the only excuse you need for your own personal policies.

‚Ä¢¬†All guns are loaded.

‚Ä¢ Many backward steps are made by standing still.

‚Ä¢¬†This is the best time ever to make something. None of the greatest, coolest creations 20 years from now have been invented yet. You are not late.

‚Ä¢¬†No rain, no rainbow.

‚Ä¢ Every person you meet knows an amazing lot about something you know virtually nothing about. Your job is to discover what it is, and it won‚Äôt be obvious.

‚Ä¢¬†You don‚Äôt marry a person, you marry a family.

‚Ä¢¬†Always give credit, take blame.

‚Ä¢ Be frugal in all things, except in your passions splurge.

‚Ä¢¬†When making something, always get a few extras ‚Äî extra material, extra parts, extra space, extra finishes. The extras serve as backups for mistakes, reduce stress, and fill your inventory for the future. They are the cheapest insurance.

‚Ä¢ Something does not need to be perfect to be wonderful. Especially weddings.

‚Ä¢¬†Don‚Äôt let your email inbox become your to-do list.

‚Ä¢¬†The best way to untangle a knotty tangle is not to ‚Äúuntie‚Äù the knots, but to keep pulling the loops apart wider and wider. Just make the mess as big, loose and open as possible. As you open up the knots they will unravel themselves. Works on cords, strings, hoses, yarns, or electronic cables.

‚Ä¢¬†Be a good ancestor. Do something a future generation will thank you for. A simple thing is to plant a tree.

‚Ä¢ To combat an adversary, become their friend.

‚Ä¢¬†Take one simple thing ‚Äî almost anything ‚Äî but take it extremely seriously, as if it was the only thing in the world, or maybe the entire world is in it ‚Äî and by taking it seriously you‚Äôll light up the sky.

‚Ä¢¬†History teaches us that in 100 years from now some of the assumptions you believed will turn out to be wrong. A good question to ask yourself today is ‚ÄúWhat might I be wrong about?‚Äù

‚Ä¢¬†Be nice to your children because they are going to choose your nursing home.

‚Ä¢¬†Advice like these are not laws. They are like hats. If one doesn‚Äôt fit, try another.

For more see my previous 68 Bits of Unsolicited Advice.

Translation in Italian. Chinese.

Tags

  2. webmark
  3. swipes (Private)

noteIndex.title: /root

all-notes-should-be-relative-to-me.text: All notes should be relative to me.

noteIndex.body:
# Welcome to Noetic Noggin

This is [[my|archive.about]] personal wiki and a commonplace book; notes by me, for me.

üöß Permanently under construction üöß

![](https://res.cloudinary.com/zubayr/image/upload/v1658499909/wiki/ajevkuyebljlxiblyst2.png)

This wiki was made possible with [dendron.so](https://dendron.so) and [obisidian.md](https://obsidian.md). Stored on [Github Repository](https://github.com/zubayrrr/dendron) and hosted on [Netlify](https://netlify.com) for free.

## Principles

### All notes should be relative to me.

- All notes in principle are written for me; what I know about a subject, how I feel about a particular thing.
- Opinions are fine as long as I feel strong epistemic confidence in the given opinion.
- Don't over explain a note if it's not necessary, remember, these notes are for you and are relative to whatever knowledge you posses about the subject.
- Read books and make an dedicated notes for them.
- Listen podcasts but capture them inside a "subject specific" note or "Map of Concept" note or a note tagged #areas. Because making notes from podcasts can be tedious as they're not as well structured as books for consumption.(Whose merit is debatable.)
- #areas are basically "Map of Concept" notes but I have recently come to the realization that its better to maintain them [Nikita Voloboev style](https://wiki.nikiv.dev/) but with heavy usage of transclusion and backlinking.
  - "Resources" should be first processed and then mentioned inside the note, otherwise they should be left in inbox.

### Gotta capture 'em all

- Hog whatever information tickles your pickle([anything that gratifies one's intellectual curiosity](https://news.ycombinator.com/newsguidelines.html)).
- [[swipes]] are interesting/useful bits of... [[quotes|swipes.quotes]], [[excerpts|swipes.excerpts]], [[sayings|swipes.sayings]], [[phrases|swipes.phrases]]. Essentially, ideas, opinions that are swiped off from [[others|resources.people]].
- Make no distinction between "your" ideas and ideas of "others", because if you vibe with an idea; it's already yours.
- But also remember "If you've time to consume, you've time to produce.".
- Use [raindrop.io](https://raindrop.io) to manage your URL bookmarks.
- If you need to bookmark a webpage or an article all together, use [MarkDownload](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/markdownload-markdown-web/pcmpcfapbekmbjjkdalcgopdkipoggdi?hl=en-GB) to rip the entire page. Let's call it a [[webmark|inbox.webmark]]; it belong in the `/inbox`.
- Similar process is employed for capturing tweets using [tweet-to-markdown](https://github.com/kbravh/tweet-to-markdown) and it also belongs in the `/inbox`.

### Don't force evolution

- Let your second brain evolve at it's own pace.
- The structure should never be _too_ rigid because its meant to take form by itself.

### Noise & Signal

- While capturing ideas left and right is recommended, make sure you're not harming your periods of focus.
- Have impenetrable focus periods (use Pomodoro method) where you only care about the work on hand and nothing else.

### Why do any of this?

- Because I can't remember everything - there's a lot of information around that interests me and there isn't enough working memory installed in me.
- So, I make notes - to remember, to create, to meditate, to think.
- A bodybuilder's portfolio is their body - my portfolio is my wiki.
- Not only am I making - whatever I know - tangible by writing it down. I know exactly where to look if I ever forget something.
- I am at the beginning of my learning adventures. When I look back at it, I will know where I came from and how my thoughts evolved over time.
- Plus, its really fun to nerd out.

## Structure of this wiki

- [[slipbox.Ontology]] explains the structure of this wiki and the tags, backlinks used in it.
- Dendron takes care of the structure and hierarchy(mostly), but I insist on using tags for backwards compatibility.

## Quicklinks

- [[About me|archive.about]]
- [Github](https://github.com/zubayrrr)
- [Twitter](https://twitter.com/zoobhalu)
- [Blog](https://zubayrali.in)
- [Guestbook](https://www.yourworldoftext.com/~zubayrali/)
